channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: Can eggs cause cancer? Viral claim by Indian doctor is sparking concern
Trump Gold Card is here: Which US visa does it replace? How does it differ from green card?
Quicksplained | Indian-origin man held in Canada for flashing women doctors: What we know so far
Why Bangladesh’s 2026 elections matter to India
Will you have to declare 5-year social media history for US tourist visa soon?
US-Venezuela tension: How far is Donald Trump willing to go?
A nation in turmoil: Why Imran Khan still terrifies Pakistan Army
item.description: The ongoing battle in Pakistan is not between Imran Khan and Shehbaz Sharif, who is a puppet of the Army. It is between Imran Khan and the coterie of generals led by Field Marshal Asim Munir.

item.title: How Modi and Putin re-energised India-Russia multilateral cooperation
item.description: The nature and scope of cooperation in various multilateral institutions, which often finds Russia and India pursuing the same causes and goals, are wide-ranging.

item.title: Trump’s threat of new tariffs on Indian rice deepens trade standoff
item.description: A major breakthrough should not be expected in the immediate future, as the new tariff threats create a difficult environment for compromise.

item.title: Rushdie’s duplicity: How a victim of ‘Islamist knife’ finds Hindu nationalism an easy target
item.description: Salman Rushdie invokes the ghost of ‘Hindu nationalism’ even when Islamists continue to aim at his life. Maybe his ‘rebellion’ is dead, and only the fear survives

item.title: A hemisphere-first strategy: Ten ways America has redrawn its global role in the new NSS
item.description: The new National Security Strategy seeks to reshape America’s position within the global order, compressing global obligations while expanding the instruments of coercive economic statecraft.

item.title: Pakistan’s overseas crackdown: A human rights test America can’t ignore
item.description: Over recent years, Pakistani journalists, activists and commentators living abroad have described a troubling pattern: speak critically of Pakistan’s military or political establishment, and the retaliation begins.
